ranked_differential_diagnosis.label: Arnold-Chiari Malformation
ranked_differential_diagnosis.rationale_short: Confirmed by MRI showing herniation of cerebellar tonsils; consistent with abnormal ABR and progressive hearing loss.

ranked_differential_diagnosis.label: Retrocochlear Pathology
ranked_differential_diagnosis.rationale_short: Indicated by abnormal ABR (extended interwave intervals) despite normal tympanometry and excellent speech recognition.

ranked_differential_diagnosis.label: Progressive Sensorineural Hearing Loss
ranked_differential_diagnosis.rationale_short: Observed clinical course of high-frequency deterioration over 15 months.

ordered_list.rationale_short: Investigate neural integrity due to possible progressive loss and asymmetry.
Follow-up on abnormal ABR to rule out structural lesions; CT and MRI performed.

expected_interpretations_by_visit.collective_interpretation: Bilateral sensorineural hearing loss with a high-frequency sloping configuration, slightly worse in the left ear. Speech recognition is excellent. Tympanometry is normal, and acoustic reflexes are present. However, ABR is abnormal bilaterally with extended I-V intervals, suggesting neural involvement.

tests.name: Pure-tone audiometry
tests.result_summary: Bilateral SNHL, ~20-30 dB HL in lows sloping to ~40-50 dB HL in highs.

tests.name: Acoustic reflexes
tests.result_summary: Present at normal to slightly elevated levels (85-105 dB HL).

tests.name: Auditory Brainstem Response (ABR)
tests.result_summary: Abnormal bilaterally; extended I-V intervals (~4.78ms RE, ~4.88ms LE) due to extended I-II and III-V.

expected_interpretations_by_visit.collective_interpretation: Monitoring over 15 months shows progressive high-frequency hearing loss. Speech recognition remains excellent. Imaging (MRI) confirms Arnold-Chiari Malformation, explaining the neural signs.

tests.name: Pure-tone audiometry
tests.result_summary: Progressive loss; lows ~30-40 dB HL, highs dropping to ~60-80 dB HL.

tests.name: Diagnostic Imaging
tests.result_summary: CT normal. MRI showed herniation of cerebellar tonsils through foramen magnum (Arnold-Chiari Malformation).

counseling_actions: Explain the progressive nature of the sensorineural hearing loss
Discuss ABR and MRI findings indicating Arnold-Chiari Malformation
Advise on the necessity of neurosurgical consultation
Highlight that speech understanding remains excellent despite threshold shifts

red_flags_present: Progressive sensorineural hearing loss in a child

escalation.rationale_short: Decompressive craniotomy indicated for Arnold-Chiari Malformation.

follow_up_plan.objective: Monitor stability of hearing thresholds and ABR, and track developmental/academic progress.

expected_outcome: Hearing and ABR are stable post-surgery.
Child is making progress with hearing aids and academic support.
